wikipedia_page.main: George Sutherland Fraser (8 November 1915 – 3 January 1980) was a Scottish poet, literary critic and academic.

**George Sutherland Fraser, Scottish poet and critic (born 1915)
The poet George Sutherland Fraser, who served in World War II, wrote a poem, "S.S. City of Benares (drowned refugee children, 1940)", about the sinking.
* January 3 – George Sutherland Fraser (born 1915), Scottish poet and critic
* November 8 – George Sutherland Fraser (died 1980), Scottish-born poet and critic
*George Sutherland Fraser (1915–1980), Scottish poet, literary critic and academic
* 8 November – George Sutherland Fraser, poet and critic (died 1980 in Leicester)

Fraser was born on 8 June 1949.'FRASER, Helen Jean Sutherland', Who's Who 2017, A & C Black, an imprint of Bloomsbury Publishing plc, 2017; online edn, Oxford University Press, 2016; online edn, Nov 2016 accessed 14 Nov 2017 Her father was George Sutherland Fraser, the poet and literary critic. She was educated at the Collegiate Girls' School, an all-girls independent school in Leicester. She studied English language and literature at St Anne's College, Oxford, and graduated with a Bachelor of Arts (BA) degree in 1970; as per tradition, her BA was later promoted to a Master of Arts (MA Oxon) degree.

*The Scottish writer and scholar George Sutherland Fraser lived on Beaufort Street with his mother and sister after being demobbed from the British Army following the Second World War. Fraser subsequently met his wife, Eileen Lucy Andrew, a fellow poet and resident of Beaufort Street, and the pair married in 1946.

The low print run, and the scarcity in print of Welch's other work at the time meant that reviews were similarly few in number. In The Times Literary Supplement, George Sutherland Fraser identified two features missing from Welch's poetry generally: any sense of "impersonal structure", and the effects of Welch's apparent reticence to ask for others' opinions. But as a consequence of these very absences, Fraser found "a quite unusual intimacy with his own joy and pain."The Times Literary Supplement, 30 December 1977, p. 14
